content:
lass="word-wrap-span">PICTURE IN lass="word-wrap-span">YOUR mind lass="word-wrap-span">The typical chief lass="word-wrap-span">executive. lass="word-wrap-span">The chances are that you have thought of someone male, in a suit and lass="word-wrap-span">distinguished-looking. In part, that is because most bosses look like that. It may also be because people lass="word-wrap-span">instinctively lass="word-wrap-span">defer to such types.

In their book “lass="word-wrap-span">Messengers: lass="word-wrap-span">Who We lass="word-wrap-span">Listen To, lass="word-wrap-span">Who We lass="word-wrap-span">Don’t lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">Why”, Stephen lass="word-wrap-span">Martin lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">Joseph lass="word-wrap-span">Marks, two psychologists, outline how people respond to visual status signals. lass="word-wrap-span">Just lass="word-wrap-span">Why are pedestrians likelier (three times as likely, according to one study) to lass="word-wrap-span">defy traffic laws to follow a man across the road when he is wearing a suit than the same man dressed in lass="word-wrap-span">denim? lass="word-wrap-span">Similarly motorists stuck at a traffic light are slower to lass="word-wrap-span">honk their horn if the car in front has a prestige brlass="word-wrap-span">And.

lass="word-wrap-span">One possibility is an lass="word-wrap-span">evolved respect for those with a higher social position. lass="word-wrap-span">This is not just about clolass="word-wrap-span">Thes or possessions. A furlass="word-wrap-span">Ther piece of research lass="word-wrap-span">cited by lass="word-wrap-span">The authors involved undergraduates who were shown photos of 50 chief lass="word-wrap-span">executives from lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Fortune 1000 list of big firms. lass="word-wrap-span">Half of lass="word-wrap-span">These bosses were from lass="word-wrap-span">The most profitable groups and lass="word-wrap-span">Half from lass="word-wrap-span">The least profitable. lass="word-wrap-span">The undergraduates were asked to judge, on looks allass="word-wrap-span">One, which lass="word-wrap-span">executives had qualities such as lass="word-wrap-span">competence and lass="word-wrap-span">dominance. lass="word-wrap-span">Remarkably, lass="word-wrap-span">The students tended to pick out those lass="word-wrap-span">executives who led lass="word-wrap-span">The most successful companies.

It is hard to lass="word-wrap-span">disentangle cause and effect. lass="word-wrap-span">But it seems more probable that people with a certain type of appearance are likely to get promoted than it is to believe they are lass="word-wrap-span">innately more lass="word-wrap-span">competent than everyone else.

lass="word-wrap-span">Humans tend to respect men with particular physical lass="word-wrap-span">characteristics. lass="word-wrap-span">When participants in a study were shown pictures of male employees of a business lass="word-wrap-span">consultancy, with similar clothes and masked faces, they perceived the taller men more positively in terms of team leadership skills. lass="word-wrap-span">Indeed, research has shown that taller and more lass="word-wrap-span">attractive men earn more than their shorter and plainer colleagues.

lass="word-wrap-span">Another business advantage for men turns out to be a face with a higher-than-average width-to-height-ratio. lass="word-wrap-span">Research showed how square-lass="word-wrap-span">jawed men negotiated higher signing-on lass="word-wrap-span">bonuses for themselves than longer-faced round-lass="word-wrap-span">jawed peers.

lass="word-wrap-span">Physical lass="word-wrap-span">characteristics also affect recruitment at lower levels. A group of Italian researchers sent CVs to a range of employers, some with photos and some without. lass="word-wrap-span">Applicants lass="word-wrap-span">deemed lass="word-wrap-span">attractive by independent scorers were 20% more likely to get an interview than the same application without a photo. lass="word-wrap-span">Things are worse for the lass="word-wrap-span">fairer sex. lass="word-wrap-span">When photos were included, male jobseekers lass="word-wrap-span">deemed unlass="word-wrap-span">attractive were contacted 26% of the time, compared with 7% in the case of unlass="word-wrap-span">attractive women.

lass="word-wrap-span">All ralass="word-wrap-span">Ther lass="word-wrap-span">depressing, particularly for women trying to climb lass="word-wrap-span">The corporate ladder. lass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">There are some intriguing differences in lass="word-wrap-span">The kind of personalities that boards tend to favour. lass="word-wrap-span">The stereotype is that lass="word-wrap-span">executives tend to be ruthless and lass="word-wrap-span">egotistical—embodied by lass="word-wrap-span">Gordon Gekko (or ralass="word-wrap-span">Ther, lass="word-wrap-span">The square-lass="word-wrap-span">jawed Michael lass="word-wrap-span">Douglas who played him). lass="word-wrap-span">Not lass="word-wrap-span">always, it turns out. lass="word-wrap-span">The authors lass="word-wrap-span">cite research on how boards choose chief lass="word-wrap-span">executives. lass="word-wrap-span">When choosing between two suitably qualified candidates to take charge of a company that is performing well, a board is likely to pick a leader who does lass="word-wrap-span">Not appear to be lass="word-wrap-span">egotistic and self-interested. lass="word-wrap-span">But if lass="word-wrap-span">The company is in trouble, a narcissist stands a better chance. lass="word-wrap-span">When lass="word-wrap-span">The going gets tough, in olass="word-wrap-span">Ther words, lass="word-wrap-span">The board opts for a lass="word-wrap-span">jerk.

lass="word-wrap-span">Perhaps board members don’t think of it that way. lass="word-wrap-span">One long-established phenomenon is the “halo effect”. If a person (or company) is rated highly in terms of lass="word-wrap-span">One lass="word-wrap-span">characteristic, it gets good marks across the board. As the authors recount, this applies when employees are being lass="word-wrap-span">assessed by their managers for qualities such as intelligence, lass="word-wrap-span">decisiveness and leadership. lass="word-wrap-span">Broadly speaking, managers divided staff into “good” and bad” workers; few employees were lass="word-wrap-span">deemed to be intelligent but lass="word-wrap-span">indecisive, for example.

lass="word-wrap-span">What this fascinating book reaffirms is lass="word-wrap-span">That people’s lass="word-wrap-span">assessments of others are lass="word-wrap-span">extremely subjective, and easily led lass="word-wrap-span">astray by appearances. lass="word-wrap-span">That suggests a lot can be achieved by using lass="word-wrap-span">artificial intelligence in hiring and promotion decisions, providing the programming is done lass="word-wrap-span">correctly and focuses on candidate qualifications. A computer shouldn’t be lass="word-wrap-span">distracted by a handsome face.
